answers.author: Katharine Greenlee
answers.text:
Hi Pamela, 
Here are some suggestions for ways to deal with pigeon problems:
Put wood or metal sheathings on flat surfaces at 45 degree angles, and if the problem is quite serious, then you can install a mild shock in the sheathings. Here is a sight for Bird Barriers: http://www.birdbarrier.com/ and discourage people from feeding pigeons. All of the above information is available at http://www.humanesociety.org/animals/pigeons/tips/solving_problems_pigeons.html
More suggestions can be found at http://www.massaudubon.org/Nature_Connection/wildlife/index.php?subject=Birds:%20Species&id=55 and www.helpinganimals.com/pdfs/PigeonReport-printable-version.pdf
Hope this helps!
Thank you, 
Katharine
Community Engagement Manager, Knowledge Network
kgreenlee@icma.org


Hi Pamela, 

Here are some suggestions for ways to deal with pigeon problems:
Put wood or metal sheathings on flat surfaces at 45 degree angles, and if the problem is quite serious, then you can install a mild shock in the sheathings. Here is a sight for Bird Barriers: http://www.birdbarrier.com/ and discourage people from feeding pigeons. All of the above information is available at http://www.humanesociety.org/animals/pigeons/tips/solving_problems_pigeons.html
More suggestions can be found at http://www.massaudubon.org/Nature_Connection/wildlife/index.php?subject=Birds:%20Species&id=55 and www.helpinganimals.com/pdfs/PigeonReport-printable-version.pdf

Hope this helps!

Thank you, 
Katharine

author: Pamela Muse
text:
An Alliance member is dealing with pigeon problems in residential areas.  Currently the County Health department deals with pigeons in non-residential areas.  Looking for any creative ideas/efforts that cities have successfully implemented to deal with pigeons.
Thank you!
Pamela Muse
Western Regional Director
Alliance for Innovation
888-468-6450 Voice
480-231-3538 Text
pmuse@transformgov.org
title: Residential Pigeon Problem
